div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

THURSDAY, JANUARY 2, 1908.

div.head: GREAT BIBLICAL DISCOVERY IN EGYPT
div.p: One discovery follows fast on another in Egypt. Now, on the very heels of the dis covery of Menander, we have what looks much like the recovery of lost chapter from the Book of Nehemiah, at Assouan, for some extraordinary papyri has been found by excavators in Egypt which showed that the Jews had a temple there as well as in Jerusalem.

Previously some Jewish business fragments had been found which showed that the Jews in Egypt in Jeremiah's time worshipped Jehovah under the name of Yahu. But M. Clermont-Ganneau has given "Le Teumps" an account of this new discovery, and the translation made by the German scholar, Dr. Sachan. The document is a copy of a petition sent by the Jews of Elephantine, an island at Assouan to the Persian Governor Bagohi (Bagoas of Josephus), in the seventeenth year of Darius telling how, when Egypt was conquered by Cambyses, their Jewish temple was spared, while the Egyptian temples were destroyed. But during the absence of the Satrap of Egypt the worshippers of the god Khnum had persuaded the local Governor to give orders to have their temple destroyed, and during the three years since they had been in deep mourning.

"They had appealed in vain for help to the Jewish high priest Jehohanan, and had written to the acts of Sanballat at Samaris, and now they begged Bagohi to allow them to rebuild their temple, in which case they would be able to burn incense there, and would pray for him and send him a thousand talents of silver. This petition was granted. The special interest of this doeument lies in the fact that it shows that in Egypt, as well as in Jerusalem, the Jews had their temple and performed ritual services. Also Sanballat and Jehohanan are both Bible characters. Sanballat was the enemy of the Jews under Nehemiah, and Jehonahan is mentioned in Ezra x. 6 and Neh. xii. 23; while this seems to be the same Jebohanan who, accord King to Josephus, murdered his brother Joshua.

We are able to give our readers an English translation of part of this remarkable letter for which we are indebted to professor Driver, in the London "Guardian". Thus we have it a accredited by three of the very best Oriental scholars of Germany, France, and England - Professor Sachau, M. Clermont-Gauneau and Professor Driver. It i s follows:
"To our lord Bagohi, Governor of Judah, thy servants, Yedoniah and his companions, the priests, in the fortress Yeb (Blephantine)

"From the Tammuz day of the 14th year of King Darias to this day we have put on sack cloth and fasted; our wives are become like widows; we have not anointed ourselves with oil or drunk wine ; neither from that day to this day of the 17th year of King Darius (40 B.C.) have meal offerings frankincense, or burnt-offerings been offered in this Temple. Now, therefore, thy servante, Yedoniah and his companions, and the Jews, all the citzens of Yeb, may thus: If it seem good to our lord, think upon this Temple that it may be built, because we are not permitted to build it, look spon the recipients of thy goodness and of thy mercy who are here in Egypt

"May a letter be sent from thee to them concerning the Temple of the God Yahu that it may built in the fortress Yeb, as it was built in former times. And we will offer meal offering and frankincense and burnt offerings upon the altar of the God Yahu in thy name. And we will pray for thee at all times, we and our wives and our children, and all the Jews who are here, if thou doest thus, until the Tenuple is built. And thou shalt have a portion before Yahu, the God of Heaven, from every one who offers to him burnt-offering and sacrifices, in value equivalent to... And no concerning the gold, concerning that we have sent we made known. We huve also sent the matters in letter in our name to Delaiah and Shelemiah, the sons of Sarballat, the Governor of Samarin.
Ansam also has no knowledge of all this that has been done to as.
"The 20th of Marcheshvan (November), in the 17th year of King Darius.'

What is of very great interest is this almost biblical record in the fact that a splendid temple of Jehovah was in existence in Upper Egypt shortly after the time of Jeremiah; that sacrifices were offered there as at Jerusalem, notwithstanding the prohibition, and that the name of Jehovah was in free use under the pronunciation Yahu

There is now no reason why we may not hope to find in Egypt copies of the old Hebrew Seriptures antedating the revision of the text which took place in the first century of our era. That would be a discovery indeed.

div.head: GO TO LIVADAS.
div.p: Opposite Shepheard's
for Books, Stationery, Newspapers, and "Egyptian Gazette” Picture Post Cards.

div.head: Death.
div.p: At "Colga House," Slige, Iceland, Robert Anderson, (Poor Law Guardian, etc.,) 18th December 1907, brother-in-law of Mr. Justine Neary, Provincial Magistrate of Masloha and beloved uncle of C.W. Anderson-Neary, Alexandria, Egypt, Cape and Australian papers copy.

div.head: The "Stein."
div.p: The German training ship "Stein" left this morning for Naples.

div.head: A New Year gift.
div.p: The Delta Lodge, Tentah, have paid L.E. 2 to the Rudolph Home, Alexandria, for the poor.

div.head: The Alexandria Press
div.p: Our former contemporary "Les Nouvelles" will be resuscitated on Saturday. We wish it a long and healthy life.

div.head: Standard Life Assurance Companu
div.p: The new Cairo offices of this Company are now in the building of the Egyptian Estates Company, close to the Savoy Hotel.

div.head: Kaar-el-Nil Bridge
div.p: Kaar-el-Nil Bridge will be open (closed to road traffic) at 11.30 AM, and closed (open to road traffie) at 1 p.m., to-day and to-morrow.

div.head: Cholera
div.p: Our Suez correspondent reports that three cholera patients from the French pilgrim steamer "Livernala" have been quarantined at Suez.

div.head: A. R. M. D. S.
div.p: The inaugural concert of the Alexandria and Ramleh Amateur Musical and Dramatic Society will take place at the Savoy Palace Hotel at 9.30 to-morrow evening.

div.head: The Municipal Loan
div.p: The National Bank of Egypt announces that Coupon No. 12 of the City of Alexandria 4 per Cent. Loan, due Jandary 1, 1908, will be paid on and after that date at 4 and 5, King William Street, City.

div.head: The Book Club ALexandria
div.p: We are requested to inform the members that in future the library will be open three times a week and that there will be a slight modification in the hours of changing. Books can be exchanged on Mondays, Wednesday, and Fridays from 4 to 5.15 p.m.

div.head: Mariout Railway
div.p: The new service of trains on the Khedive's line, which came inte operation yesterday, is a decided improvement. Now instead of the long train journey to Wardian, the train starts from Bab el-Ghedid Station. The morning train leaves for Mariout at 11.30 o'clock ond returns to Bab el-Ghedid at 5.30 p.m.

div.head: An Effect of the Crisis
div.p: Owing to the stoppage of building at Alexandria there has been a big fall in the stone of the chief building materials. Lime and sand have fallen by 25 percent. Mex stone, which used to cost nine dollars per mille, is now at five and a half dollars. Bricks have fallen from P.T. 120 to P.T. 80 per mille.

div.head: Casino San Stefano
div.p: The Concert given yesterday on the terrace of the Casino by the band of the Royal Inninkilling Fusiliers was very successful. The aristocracy of Alexandria mustered in force and it is to be hoped that the management will continue to give military concerts every Sunday which would be a great attraction during the winter season.

div.head: Elections at Cairo
div.p: Shiekh Ali Youssef was elected member of the Legislative Council at the election held at the Cairo Government on Thursday morning and four candidates were also elected to the General Assembly. These were Mohammed Pusha Hassan, Ibrahim Rey Ragie, Hassan Mohammed Abu Saida, and Shiekh Abdarheim Abdermardash.

div.head: A Case of Leve Majeste
div.p: Mr. Apostopoulos, Editor of the Greek newspaper, "Bosforos," of Cairo, who has been in prison for some months on the charge of having been guilty of "Leve Majeste" towards the King of Greece, was acquitted on Friday last by the Hellenic Assize Court of Alexandria, in spite of the energetic pleading for the prosecution of Mr. Scotidis, the Consul General who acted as Crown Prosecutor.

div.head: The Map Exhibition
div.p: As previously announced an exhibition of the maps of Egypt now being published by the Government will be held in the Geological Museum, Cairo. The Khedive will open the exhibition on January 9, after which it will be open to the public daily from 9 a.m. to 4.30 p.m. up to January 18 inclusive. Examples will be shown of instruments used in surveying; methods controlling the accuracy of survey work; methods of reproducing maps and plans; methods of utilizing maps for statistical and other purposes; topographical maps of different part of Egypt. Admission will be free.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: The plague returns for the past year show an increase on the figures of previous years, the cases which have been tested numbering 1,213 in 1907 in against 631 in 1906 and 266 in 1905. There are at present eleven cases under treatment, nineteen fresh cases appeared during the past week, and for that period twelve deaths and seven cures are recorded. The infected districts of the week ending the 21st December ulto. were as follows: Alexandria 3, Damiette 1, Deirout 14, and Aghagha 1. Yesterday's bulletin announces a new admission to hospital at Deirout and one death there. One plague case was cured at Simbellawein.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: INTERESTING INTERVIEW.
(Gazette's special service.)
London, Thursday.

The Cairo correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" has sent a long and interesting account of an interview with the Khedive. His Highness said that he was thoroughly satisfied and gratified with the progress that Egypt was making and that he was convinced that he and his advisers were treading in the right path. The Khedive, however, added that much remained still to be done. His people were dependent on their agricultural labour and as long as the chief produce of the country was cotton and the present prices were maintained, the prosperity of the country most inevitably go on increasing, as the area under cultivation was over widening.

The Khedive expressed his delight at the return of Sir Eldon Gorst to Egypt and remarked on the sympathetic and enlightened interest which he took in the country. In referring to education he said that he was proud of the progress the Egyptians were making in this direction. The Khedive remarked that be deeply deplored the tendency of a few young Egyptians to seek self advertisement rather than the improvement of their country by legitimate means. He was delighted, however, that all agitation was dying out and he emphasised the entire absence of fanaticism. Referring to the Sudan his Highness declared that he had every confidence in the Sirdar and his staff and was gratified at the very material progress made during the last few years. In concluding the interview the Khedive declared that he would be delighted if Lord Cromer were to revisit Egypt.

div.head: DISTRESS IN INDIA
div.p: (Garette's Special Service)
London, Wednesday.
The Governor General of India reports that rain is urgently needed. Everywhere distress is increasing owing to scarcity and the higher prices.

div.head: THE WEATHER AT HOME
div.p: (Gazette's special services)
London, Wednesday. The weather is inten-ely cold throughout England and skating is expected to be possible shortly.

div.head: LORD KITCHENER G.C.I.E.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
London, Wednesday.
The New Year honours are confined to the Indian list Lord Kitchener has been created Knight Grand Commander of the Indian Empire.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive left Sidi Abdul Rahman yesterday morning and come by the Mariout line to Amrieh where he slept last night. To day his Highness has gone to Hamnan to inspect his condensers and will return to Montazah this evening.
The Khedive will return to Cairo on Saturday.

div.head: SHOUBRA ENGLISH SCHOOL
div.p: Lady Gorat was present on Monday afternoon at the juvenile operetta "Queen Bee" which was performed by the children of the Shoubra English School, Cairo, and afterwards distributed the prizes to the successful scholars of last year. These prizes should bave been distributed in June last, but sufficient accomodation being at that time unavailable it was decided to postpone the event until the school had been completed. The operetta was charmingly performed, Miss Marjorie Flowers playing the part of Huzzy remarkably well and little Miss Aldred also did full justice to the part of Buzzy. Master Aitkin headed the list of prize winners with four prizes Master McPhee coming next with three. After a distribution of sweets and presents from a Christmas tree the children were enternained to tea by Mrs. Foote, who had also supplied the prizes, and the Christmas three, the ladies of the choir and congregation of All Saints Church assisting at the tables.

div.head: CAIRO SCIENTIFIC SOCIETY
div.p: The sixty-seventh meeting of the Society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kaar-el-Aini, this afternoon when, the President will move the following resolution:-- "That the annual subscription of the Society be increased to P.T. 120 to cover the cost of publication of the proceedings of the Society" after which the election of subcommittee for Arabie education will take place.
Dr. W. H. Wilson, will give a demonstration of a scheme for showing the mechanical factors of the circulation.
On Friday next the members of the society are invited to inspect the Helouan Observatory, by invitation of Mr. B.F.E. Keeling. The train leaves Bab-el-Louk station at 2.15.

div.head: THE VIBORG MANIFESTO.
div.p: DUMA MEMBERS SENTENCED.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Wednesday.
The trial of the members of the first Dama who circulated the Viborg manifesto has been concluded. 167 deputies have been sentenced to three months' imprisonment and the loss of political rights.
KAID MACLEAN'S RELEASE.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday. The "Globe" publishes a letter from Kaid Moolean to Messrs. Greener,genmakers, stating that he hopes to be released this week.
SCOTTISH RAILWAYS (Qaretto's Spoolal Service).
London, Wednesday. A working arrangement between the North British and Caledonian Railways in announced in relation to competitive traffio.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: Mr. Detrooz, Belgian Pretnier, is dead.

div.head: THE CHOLERA EPIDEMIC.
div.p: THE PROTECTION OF EGYPT.
The following is a translation of a notice isced by the Quarantino Board :

Shipping Agents, ships captaing, and pilgrims are informed that on the return from the Hedjaz they will only be allowed to take provisions from the Tor encampment, and that it is forbidden, in the most oategorical manner, to take provisions either from Suez or from Port Said.

The Quarantine Board has made an agree ment with the Clayton Gas Company of Rgypt and the Sudan Ltd, for the disinfection of steamers frequenting the porta of Alexandria Port Said, Suez and Tor. The Company is now engaged in pushing ahead the work of installing the various plants in those port. In view of the recent rumours of trouble in the Levant as to cholem this effective and remedial measure is well-timed and the Quar antine Buard is to be congratulated on having adopted the best possible methods of disinfection.

THE NEW YEAR. The New Year has been ushered in at Alexandrin is right royal manner. There were many family and friendly gatherings to "ring out the old, ring in the new," and the senti ment attached to the s on was sustained in true Christian like spirit. Hands were clapaed that had been withheld during the year, and friendliness was master of the ceremonies. Those who are condemned to a life of solitado and were not invited to join some family gathering made little parties among themselves and spent the ove and, in many cases, the first evening of the New Year, in public places. The hotels were quite busy. At the Savoy Palace symptous dinners were served on both nights and the other hotels were equally liberal with their fares. We cannot omitmen tion of our German friends, many of whom aasembled in the "Germania and around wonderfully modelled "Freya and heavily do conated Christmas tree, both electrically light od, joined hands to welcome the arrival of 1908. May it be a more prosperous one than 1907 was the warmly expressed wish of one and all, and it is such a wish that we send far and wide to reach the thousands who will read there few lines.

PIGS IN EGYPT Last week a large consignment of pigs ar rived at Alexandria from Servis, Bulgaria, Crete and Cyprus. On previous Occasions the pigs have solely arrived here from Rhodes and Cyprus. The Bulgarian pigs have been admitted to free pratique here by the Que rantine suthorities. But the Servian pigs, which are of very distinguished appearance, reminding one of our best home, breeds, have been kept in quarantine and will be killed in the course of the next few days at the slaughterhouses at Alexandria. The Cretan piga are fairly good. The total arrivals of pige last week at Alexandris were over six hundred. It is not, however, to be expected that pork will be any the cheaper, for butchers' prices in this country always go up, just as do the rents, despite the crisis Up to date over 250,000 abeep bave arrived at Alexandria from various sources since the beginning of the year, which is largely over the imports for any previous year, and yet the price of mutton never goes down, bat on the contrary shows an opward tendeney.

div.head: LONDON BANK RATE
div.p: PROSPECT OF BEING LOWERED.
(Gazette's Speciaal Service.)
London, Tuesday.
The Bank of England has secured a large quantity of gold. If the influx continues the bank rate may possibly be lowered on Thursday.

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORM
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Wednesday.

Ambassadors firmly insist on the renewal for seven years of the powers of agents in Macedonia and have rejected the proposal that the agents be paid by Turkey as this would destroy their independence.

div.head: VALUABLE PAPYRUS DISCOVERY.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
London, Wednesday.

Lang Freer, the well known Detroit capitalist and art connoisseur, confirms the authenticity of the reported discovery in Egypt of valuable ancient papyrus, which will enable important additions to be made to Biblical lore.
(Further particulars of this discovery will be found in our leader on Page 2. Ed. E.G)

div.head: THE PERSIAN SITUATION.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday.
Troubles are brewing in northern Persia. The importation of arms is increasing.

div.head: CHRISTMAS AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Port Sudan, December 26.

A smoking concert was held on Christinas Eve in the band room of the new barracks, which was splendidly decorated for the occasion with flags and bunting and made an excellent room for the concert. The chair was taken by Kaimakam W. B Drury Bey. Needless to say the concert was a decided success, and among the many who volunteered to perform was Mr. Buxton, who related a few of his experiences and many witty tales, while Mr. Hamer sang and Mr. Koop played the violin. Mr. Pool's songs were appreciated by all present, and many encores were called for. Although it rained very hard just before the start most of the English population decided to brave the elements and turned up. The concert finished up at 2.30 a.m. with the Khedivial Anthem, and "God save the King," after which three cheers were given for the chairman.

On Christmas Day, service was held in the church, which had been splendidly decorated. The Rev. Thom officiated and many people were present. On this day most of the houses and the ships in harbour were decked out with bunting, the S.S. "Prince Abbas" making an especially fine display.
FREGOLI

Fregoli !- The very name carries with it an air of wonderment and mystery, and ever since Alexandrians awoke one fine morning to find the weird name on every other paving stone, Fregoli has haunted them. It is now hardly necessary to describe who or what Fregoli is, but sufficient to voice the opinion of all who have witnessed his performance at the Alhambra Theatre, as marvellous. His versatility is illimitable, his portrayal of various characters never ending, and the perfection of his lightning changes combined with accurate attention to every detail, even to deflexions of voice, of every character he represents, stamp him as an artist of the first water.

With a continual change of programme he does not tire his audiences with repetitions, and although one may have seen a previous performance, a second visit is not only advisable, but almost a necessity to realise his capabilities. One may see him as a conductor impersonating past and present lights of the musical world, and yet have no idea what he can do as a magician à là Maskelyne and Devant, or sit and revel in his Louie Fuller serpentine dance, and then not realise the perfection of his one-man-six-character representation of "Faustino." It is almost impossible to detail even one of his performances, we would rather criticise a whole opera company, than attempt it, but one thing we must individualise; the continual strain, and it must be excessive, of running a one-man entertainment is having its effect upon Fregoli's voice, as at our last visit a distinct and painful hoarseness was noticeable at every breath. We however, trust this is only a temporary indisposition, and that he will continue to delight crowded houses during the remainder of his stay at the Alhambra.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Papayanni liner "Fabian" sailed yesterday for Liverpool with 4319 bales of cotton.

div.head: Port Said Strike
div.p: A SERIOUS SITUATION.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Port Said, Tuesday.

The first batch of 200 blacklegs arrived here last night from Cairo and up country. It was rumoured that these men were due to arrive on Sunday afternoon and that several hundred strikers armed with sticks awaited their arrival, intending to give them a warm welcome. On their arrival yesterday, however, everything was quiet; they were met and escorted, to the harbour by the mounted police from Cairo. Special accommodation has had to be built on the east side of the canal, while some firms have built covers to lighters and have housed them there.
Referring to my notes of Sunday, my statement that the Arabs are not underpaid is fully confirmed by the fact that Europeans are offering themselves for the same work and pay.

There have been several disturbances in the Arab village more or less serious and last night I understand a store house was broken into and ransacked. It is difficult to obtain official information as no one, European or Native, is allowed in or out of the Arab village without a special permit, while the Port Said police have handed over the patrolling of the village to the Cairo drafts.

div.head: SOCIETE DES CONCERTS.
div.p: Last Sunday's programme was perfect, almost too perfect. It was one unbroken succession of all that appealed to emotion, intellect, and mood; first came the Glück, Iphigenia, solemn vivid clear cut and graceful as a Greek statue, then the Handel concerto, archaic, rather, architectural, replete with the symbolism of a Gothic cathedral; who can forget the grave sorrow of those minor notes closing a passage, or the high dignity of the ending, determinate and faultless, the delicacy and strength of the movement, of every note. And then the death of Isolde, the crowning wonder of all that love had know, hoped, regretted, remembered, as the long years crystallised golden moments, lingering until those great mists of passion annihilated all things
The fitting contrast, ronction-and how one crarea for a reaétion after Tristan and Isolda!

- the Peer Gynt, that weird travelled phantasy, from Morocco to the mountains of the North, dawn, the hero's death, the eastern dance, and the revel of the gromes about the spiers of the mountains : - after this the Tchaikowsky march, showing Napoleon in retreat, Rasin triomphant, barbarig, outrageous children at fair, and, through it all, the wind shrieking to the blank snow onder dark stripped trees.

The performance was, all through, distinctly adequate. The orchestra is really excellent : soch slight hesitations s e rred were unmistakenly due to the insufficiency of the rehemals, inevitable when we think what a quantity of work the opera orchestra has the whole week through. One had to take exception to the conduoting in parts: that, I think, is chiefly due to temperament: for example, in the Tristan and Inolda, M. Baron hardly realised the full atmosphere, the resonant magie of the music in the Gring, he was inclined to monotony, he could not attain the almost elfish and rhythm of the far North

The Marche did well-Tehaikowsky site him, do Glock and Handel One did wish for the old open keyless trumpets, the viol de Gambe, all those instruments for which Glick wrote, and which would have brought out the clear purity of the musie: modern instru ments seem to stifle it. M. Vallette wag SaintSains Henry VIII sir it does not suit his voice: it is too mournful, and he introduced An a ry tremolo, he is sentially dramatic, rather than onert singer. I must praise the excellence of some of the instruments, the horns all through the violina in Tristas, sad the best in the Tehnikowaky, Altogether it was most impressive programme and will given

SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL CAIRO The small dance which is held weekly at Shepherd's Hotel, Cairo, falling on New Year's are there was an exceptionally large attendance on Today evening the halls and corridors being thronged with visitors from an warly hour in the evening. The orchestra was repeatedly called upon for encore and it Inoked beta few minutes to midnight when the last dance before supper was finished As the old your is passing gave place to the new the big gong rang out the strokes of the bour, and immediately an army of waiten appeared, bearing trays of steaming punch, while others bore & goodly supply of dough-outs
THE KAISER INTERVIEWED.
HIIS VISIT TO ENGLAND,
THE HAPPY COUNTRY"
LONDON, December 31.

Mr. Edward Dicey publishes in the "Empire Review” an interview with the Emperor Wilham. His Majesty said that, as the eldest grandson of Queen Victoria, to whom he was deeply attached, he felt most keenly that he had been regarded in England as hostile to Great Britain. His reception in England was accordingly most welcome. Hitherto be had known only the Court life in England, but now he had learnt to know the country and the people. He was impressed with the wealth, dignity and life of the country gentlemen, the independence and kindliness of the peasants. England was best describable as the happy country. His Majesty hoped that Germany would soon take more interest in sports, of which perhaps the English were az little too fond. Regarding trade the Emperor William was all in favour of the open door policy although it was impossible at present to introdace it into Germany. (Reuter)
THE VIBORG MANIFESTO.
DUMA MEMBERS SENTENCED.
Sr. PETERSBURG, Jannary 1.

167 members of the first Duma have been sentenced to three months imprisonment and the loss of their electoral rights for the issuing of the famous Viborg manifesto, protesting against the dissolution and inciting people to refuse to pay taxes or send recruits. The lightness of the sentence is regarded as a victory for the popular cause. (Reuter)
DEATH OF FRENCH SENATOR
Paris, December 31.
M. Guyot Dessaigne, Minister of Justice, fell dead this morning in the precincts of the Senate. (Reuter)
London, January 1.
Sir H. Campbell Bannerman has telegraphed to M. Clemencean his condolences on the death of M. Dessaigne. (Reuter)
CONTRABAND OF ARMS.
TANGIER, December 31.
The Sultan of Morocco has authorized France and Spain to control the contraband of arms in Moroccan waters. (Reuter)
REVOLT IN PORTUGUESE GUINEA.
London, December 31.
The "Times" learns from Lisbon that an alarming revolt bas taken place in Portuguese Guinea. Europeans are in urgent need of assistance. An expedition will be sent. (Renter)
A BOURSE GAS EXPLOSION.
ROME, December 31.

A gas explosion has occurred in the Bourse here. It shattered the windows and brought down the roof. A dozen stock brokers were more or less seriously injured. Troops and firemen hastened to the scene and conveyed the injured persons to the hospital.
(Later). Most of the injured persons were messengers and not brokers. (Renter)
THE MOROCCAS SITUATION.
MARAKESH, January 1.
143 prisoners taken by the Meballa of Mouley Hafid have arrived. (Havas)
ORAN, January 2.

General Lyantey telegraphs that he has eflected a decisive sweeping movement of the various columns on the Algerian frontier and occupied the passes. The tribesmen are surrendering and paying fines. (Reuter)

ITALY AND AUSTRIA
ROME, January 2.
Signor Tittoni and Baron d'Aehrefithal exchanged the most cordial telegrams hoping the New Year would draw still closer the happy relations between the two countries. (Reuter)
BOMB IN BARCELONA,
BARCELONA, January 1.
A bomb thrown in the streets has killed two people. (Havas)
THE COTTON STRIKE.
MANCHESTER, January 1.
In view of the continued refusal of employers to yield, the cotton operatives have decided to add a fourth mill to the strike list bringing up the total of idle hands to 2000.
(Reuter)
THE HARDEN CASE.
BERLIN, January 1.

The Harden case is drawing to its close. The prosecution contended that Harden did not produce a shred of evidence against Moltke and Eulenburg. He demanded four months imprisonment and payment of the costs of both trials. (Reuter)
THE FRENCH BUDGET.
PARIS, January 1.
The Senate and the Chamber have finally passed the budget. (Reuter)
NUNCIO IN BELGIUM
CONSTANTINOPLE, January 1.
Archbishop Tacci, Apostolic Delegate here, has been appointed Nuncia in Belgium.
(Reuter)
A DECREASED REVENUE
LONDON, January 1.
The revenue for the nine months shows & decrease of £272,692 and for the past quarter a decrease of £1,155,182.
(Reuter)
THE AMERICAN NAVY.
LONDON, January 1.

The "Morning Post" learns from Washington that heavy shipments of ammunition and torpedoes are being despatched to the Philippines. By the time the fleet arrives, there will be a 5 years supply. (Reuter)
"TIMES" CORRESPONDENT ATTACKED.
LONDON, January 1.

Mr. Fraser, the "Times" correspondent, who was proceeding to Bagdad unescorted, has been attacked, robbed and wounded by the Kurds near Ufa. Trops are pursuing the assailants on energetic representations made by Sir N. O'Conor.
(Reuter)
THE DUCHESS OF AOSTA.
ROME, January 2
On the occasion of the New Year's parliamentary reception, the King referred to the way Egyptian climate had improved the Duchess of Aosta's health. (Reuter)
OBITUARY.
BRUSSELS, January 1.
The Premier, M. de Trooz, died yesterday evening. (Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From Our FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT.)
London, December.
The Money Market.

The monetary stringency (which generally makes itselt felt at this period of the year) has hegon to assert itself, and there is an eager demand for accomodation to carry over to the end of the year. During the earlier part of the week the rate for day to day money was as high as 6.5 per cent, and a large sum was secured from the Bank in loans and discounts at 7.5 and 7 per cert respectively.

Berlin was a large buyer of the open market, in fact, it is rumoured that the entire amount has gone to Germany, in which case it should arrive there in time to relieve the pressure which was otherwise expected at the end of the year.
A further amount of £1,800,000 of Treasury Bills has been tendered for, for which there was keen competition, the applications reaching a total of £3,585,000.
Silver

Some buying for India has caused a sharp rally in the price of silver, which advanced to 24.5d per ounce for immediate, and 24 13/16d. for forward delivery. Towards the close the tone was a little dull, owing to the fact that buying orders sagged off, and that the Eastern markets will of course be closed for the Christmas holidays
The Stock Markets.

The firm tone with which the week has commenced has caused some surprise, prices have not advanced to any extent, but there is a steady and growing demand for investment stocks. Consols have been a firm market, but have shed a 1/18 on account of the demand for gold for Germany.
Home Rails

The feature of the week has undoubtedly been Home Rails. The ratification of the working agreement between the Great Northern and Grent Central Railways at the shareholders meeting last Friday has had a beneficial effect on the stock of these two concerns, and Great Northern Deferred rose at one time to 49 1/2, but closed at 49 1/4. The "A" stock improved to 47 1/2, which represents a gain of a point. The decrease of £6,400 in the traffic return of the Brighton Line caused the "A" Stock to drop to 77 3/4, after it had touched 78 3/4. This decrease is a somewhat serious item. At the end of November the aggregate decrease for the half year looked like approaching £50,000; this however has now been exceeded, the shrinkage now being £50,273. Large economies are expected in the working of the company, and it is thought that when the figures come to be finally adjusted, these will effect the decrease in the traffic returns.
Americans

The feeling in Lombard street is that credits outstanding in America against commercial enterprises are great, and that it will take some time to bring the condition of things to a normal level. This feeling had an adverse effect on American rails, although they opened firm, and (in some of the leading issues) prices rose above parity, suffered a relapse. The offers of stock from New York did not tend to improve the situation, but added still further to the depression.
Foreign Bonds.

The prospect of a new issue of Peruvian Stock, was not very cheerfully received by the market and a large quantity of selling orders brought the price down. The Debentures dropped 2 ½ to 95 ½, the Preference 2 ¾ to 30 ¼ and the Ordinary ¾, to 7 ¼. International stocks were steady, but Paris selling caused Russian Bonds to relapse slightly.
The Mining Markets.

The Mining carry over, coming immediately after the Christmas holidays as it does, has been the means of reducing the amount of business in this department, although there has not been the stagnation that many members looked for. Some interest was infused into the Kaffir Circus by Paris buying Rand Mines, and the slight improvement in the leading speculative issues was partly due to dealings in connection with end of the year options which matured on Monday. The following particulars of dividends declared by forty six Rand Companies to date, this year, may be of interest. The total amount aggregates £6,962,500 an increase of £1,396,500 compared with 1906, when there were 39 companies declaring dividends. The outside district gold mine yielded £169,162, so that the grand aggregate is £7,131,600. Rand dividends represent 26 percent of the output and 5s 3d per sovereignn yielded.
Copper Shares.
Egyptians

There has been little business in Egyptians during the current week and price with one or to exceptions are as quoted last week. Daira Sanieh have advanced to 1/8 to 12 7/8 - 13 1/8. Delta Lands have shed to a 1/16 to 1 3/16. Land Bank of Egypt have sagged a little to 7 1/8 - 3/8. The contract which has been given to the Cleveland Bridge and Engineering Company Limited for a combined road and Railway bridge to be built across the Blue Nile at Khartoum, has created a rather favourable impression here. The length of the waterway to be crossed is not less that 1,700 ft, and the work is destined to play an important part in the development of the Lower Sudan, inasmuch that whilst permitting of the further southward extension of the Sudan railway system--which now has its termination at Halfaya (Khartoum North)--it was an essential preliminary to the great scheme devised by Sir William Garstin for the irrigation of the country lying between th Blue and White Niles. The undertaking represented the most valuable bridge contract ever placed for any part of the African continent.
The closing prices to-night are as follows:

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The Mediterranean Fleet will return to Malta from its cruise the 25th January.

The new chief engine room officer of the battleship Implacable," Engineer Commander Fred Hore has been in the service since January, 1885, and he was promoted commander in 1962. Engineer Commander S.J. Drake, who has been appointed to the cruiser "Lancaster" joined in July, 886, was promoted commander in 1905, and saw service in the expedition against the Sultan of Witu, 1890, on which occasion he was engineer lieutenant of the cruiser "Boadicea," and was in mechanical charge of the boats which proceeded to destroy the village of Mkonumbi (medal with Wita clasp) and he was engineer of the gunboat Sparrow at the bombardment of the palace of the Seltan of Zanzibar, 1896, by Sir Harry Rawson's Squadron,

The old sloop "Algerine," which has been swinging for a long time at her moorings in Hongkong harbour, is to be commissioned with a crew of 106 of all ranks for services on the West Coast of America. It is just ten years ago since she passed through the Mediterranean and the Suez Canal to her present station. The "Phoenix," her sister sloop, which accompanied her on that occasion, was completely wrecked and driven ashore in the typhoon at Hongkong on the 16th October, 1906.

The command of the 3rd Battalion King's Royal Rifles Corps, Aldershot, and orders for Crete falls vacant a little earlier than it would have by the selection of Colonel C.R.R. McGrigor, C.B., for staff service. In the ordinary course he would have completed four years in command on the 24th prox. The step should go to Major R.S. Oxley, second in command of the 1st Battalion at Cairo.

As has been already intimated in these note the Army Council have decided to adopt a longer bayonet than the regulation one in use, and to that end a modification of the Japanese bayonet, which did good work in the Far Eastern struggle is to be manufactured for use with the short magazine rifle. The new weapon is much longer that the existing one as long as the old Martini Henry rifle bayonet, triangular in formation, and tapered to a keen point in order to obviate top-heaviness. It will be cased in a leather scabbard, with black steel tip, and the fixing on will be done as in the present bayonet. The long bayonet will give the soldier a better reach in close fighting and in irregular fighting such often occurs on the frontier of the Empire.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: FIRST WINTER MEETING

FIRST DAY. The New Year opened well from the racing point of view: let us hope that everything else will start as satisfactorily. The day was warm and genial, the unpleasant winds of the last few days having kindly left us in peace. There was quite a large gathering of spectators to witness the afternoon's sport. The finishes were not quite so close, with the exception of two races, as those of the last meeting, but we saw better horses this meeting. The first race Suleik only just won by a short head, Jenkins just managing in the last stride to get him home. It looked at one time, as if Roland must win, and was the closest finish we have seen for many a day. In the Delta stakes Aurelius won easily, bat Jap who was second ran well and has a great stride. Carlton's performance was disappointing. Jenkins again was the winning jockey. We heartily congratulate Mr. Eyre on winning the steeple chase on his own horse Hector, who had been previously beaten by most of the other horses in hurdle races and this time was evidently ridden with great judgment. Challoner had a spill Mercury coming down at the water jump, and Bonser's horse pecked badly at the next jump, putting him down. In the Cairo Derby Jenkins role a great race on Mulberry, his third win in the day. --Iron Sand made a great effort to win, Jenkins only just managing to keep in front for the Breeders Stakes. Eua won comfortably, Jean d'Arc second and Firefly pulling up lame third. In the last race Mleyhan won easily, it is a pity he had not something better to run against -- he was handly expected to win. He gallops in excellent style and we wish his sporting owners luck with him. Bonser, the jockey, has unfortunately broken his collar bone, and Thompson was a good deal knocked about when Shendi came down. We regret to say Shendi was so much injured that he had to be shot. We must not forget to congratulate the handicappers, Bakri Bey and Mr. Friend on their excellent handicapping. Also we include Mr. Schreiber in our congratulations on his winning the big race, the Cairo Derby.
(FROM OUR LADY CORRESPONDENT),

Perfect weather, glorious sunshine and no wind, graced the New Year and attracted most people to Ghezireh, the only drawback to a most successful meeting being the accident to Thompson in the Cairo Derby. The bulk of spectators never realized at the first that anything untoward had happened, for the accident occured far away from the stand, and it was not until anxious towards, police and others began hurrying down the course that one realized that anything was wrong. Eventually the injured man was carried off the ground on a stretcher. Such things always cast gloom over an afternoon, but on this occasion luckily the injuries were said not to be really serious, and the events of the programme were resumed soon afterwards. The attendance was excellent. Lady Gorst was there in a pretty gown of biscuit coloured cloth with a quantity of silk braid lace about the shoulder. Lady Valda Machel was also present and the Count von Bernsdorn and his daughter, the Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Iddings with Miss Iddings in a smart grey tailor frock, her hair no longer down her back. General and Mrs. Bullock attended the meeting; it is ber first appearance since her illness, and it was also the first appearance of Mrs. Dunbar, whom we all remember as Miss Hurley. Her marriage to Capt. Dunbar who was A.D.C. to General Bullock last season, only took place in Paris a week or so ago: and they are spending the next few week with Mrs. Dauhar's sister. Mrs. Schreiber, whose wedding took place just about year ago

It is not often that Maitre Carton de Wiart is seen in the enclosure, but on this ocasion he was noticed with his small son and rephew, who are spending their holiday in Cairo. It was the first visit to Ghezireh of Mrs. Irene Hervey who had journeyed up from Helouan with Mr. R. Sharard to see how we managed such things in Egypt. She is a great horsewoman herself and has ridden in almost every country in the world and upon every type of animal. Sir John and Lady Rogers were present, the latter wearing a very pretty frock of blue and white striped muslin with lace sleeves. Mrs. Morgan's velvet coat with ermine collar etc. was charming in conjunction with the trim white skirt. Mrs. Appleton's frock of a pale blue cloth was as becoming as it could be. Princess Irene Duleep Singh were in the stand with Mrs. and Miss de B. Carey and their friends, Mrs. and Miss Shakoor was also noticed not far off. Among others distinguished in the crowd were Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, the Misses Coles, Dr. Tribe, Mrs. and Miss Schreiber, Mrs. and Mr. Raffety, Mrs. and Miss Devonshire, Judge and Miss Tuck, Mr. S. de Bilinski, Mr. Ghunter, Mr. Hamilton, Mr. Carter Wilson, Dr. and Mrs. Teale, and Mr. and Mrs. Kershaw.

Roland, Suleik and Abou Nadara were first round the turn for home. Roland looked like winning a furlong from home. Jenkins riding a strong race won by a head. Length between 2nd and third. div.head: WORDS TO WOMEN
div.p: A BUSINESS WOMAN TELLS HOW HER TIME OF SUFFERING WAS ENDED BY DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

Mrs. Roberts, who has a retaurant at 64, St. Domingo Road, Everton, feels that at middle age she has taken a new lease of life, and tells with enthusiasm how she has been restored to splendid health by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.

"If you wish me to make an affidavit as to the great benefits I have derived from Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, I will most willingly do so," she remarked to a reporter recently. "I know that in the ordinary course of nature women have to undergo an anxious experience at my time of life, and it is only in the interest of my sex that I make this statement, so that others can benefit as I have done.'
THE MOST MARVELOUS MEDICINE.
"My restoration to health," she resumed, "is solely due to what I consider the most marvellous medicine of the age, Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.

"You see I am fifty three years of age, and, having this business to superintend, I am a very busy woman, so my change of health was a very serious matter. I felt terrible pains all over my body, and sometimes my limbs felt so numbed and stiffened that I feared the approach of paralysis; and every time I moved I had an inclination to fall. My legs became swollen and inflamed, and seemed to be full of water. They became an abnormal size. My feet ached. I was never free from splitting headaches, constantly I had cold persperations, my faoe became deathly white, and my eyes were dark and sunken.
SEIZURES OF PAIN.

"My appetite entirely failed, and after a few morsels of food I felt a tearing pain in my chest, accompanied by seizures of pain in the back that almost prostrated me. The least exercise produced spasms, and as I went upstairs I would sometimes fall gasping on the staircase.

"The nights only meant increased weariness for me. In the morning when I had to go to the market I could hardly drag one leg after the other. My sight became dim, and my hearing failed me. I had a hacking cough. My trials became more severe through an attack of influenza. I lost the power of my voice and could only whisper; and a shooting, heavy pain under the heart gave me great anxiety.
A WONDERFUL CURE.

"I took many medicines, but derived no benefit from them. Then I was recommended to take Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. Before I took them I was a wasted, almost useless body, but after a few boxes of these wonderful pills I felt quite revived, and today I feel like a new woman. Through taking Dr. Williams' Pink Pills my body was nourished by new, warm blood, my limbs grow strong, my appetite became good, and I could digest my food properly. I became quite strong again. Handreds of customers come into my shop, and I never fail to tell them of the benefits I have derived from Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.
AT THE ANXIOUS TIME.

"All women understand how anxious a time is middle-age the years from forty to fifty. To many it is a time of great danger. During that trying experience the recovery of health and the protection of life depends mainly upon one thing - the supply to the system of plenty of new rich blood. This is obtained by taking Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. They have cured Women's Ailments, Anemia, General Weakness, Debility, Decline, Indigestion, Rheumatism, Neuralgia, and all Nervous Disorders. Only the genuine pills cure (substitutes are worse than useless); and these bear the full name on each package -- Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.
Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxes.

AVIS
La Municipalité met er adjudication la fourniture de Ciment néces s services pour l'année 1908.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 30 (trente.) Le cahier des charges ist déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Los offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté A Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Murticipalité avant le 14 Janvier 1908.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour A Sh.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra portieren outre la men tion "Soumission pour fourniture de ci ment."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cabier des charges, devra tre remis séparément au service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 14 Janvier 1908 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 30 Décembre 1907.

TO OUR VISITORS.

The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompaning description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.

div.p: The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer
div.p: de l'Etat
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la conpaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au dixvier 1908, à midi au plus tard des offres pour la fourni ture de six millesses ayant les dimensions de Im. 40 x 0w, 70 (un mètre quarante de long sur soixante-dix centimètres de large), livrables franco dans les Magasins généraux de Boulac (Caire, dans un délai de quinze jours partir de la date de la commande.
Les soumissionnaires devront donner leur prix en monnaio Egyptionne par cent sacs et remettre aux susdits Magasins un échantillon dos aos qu'ils ne proposent de fournir.

Pour etre admis à doncourir, le soumission naire devrs verwer su préalable à la Caisse Cen trale de l'Administration au Caire, une somme de LE 10 (dix Livres Egyptiennes) à titre de depot provisoire. Le soun.issionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somre jusqu'a concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de la valeur de la commande et ce dans les vingt quatre heures de l'avis de l'acceptation de son offre

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milliomes, ainsi que du reçu constatant le versement de dépôt provisoite et seront arressées par la poste, sous pli recommandé, à :
"Monsieur le Chef dy Service des Magasins Generaux des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat à Buo. lac, Caire" et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivantes
"Offre pour Fourniture de 6000 sacs."
L Administration ne s'engage pay à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées et elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande,
Le Caire, le 18 Décembre 1907. 31566-2-2
